section.title: Future forms
section.sectiontitle: We use be going to + verb to talk about present intentions about the future. This can be the near future or the more distant future.
section.text1a: I'm going to have a bath.
section.text2a: Jessie says she's going to be a doctor one day.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Present continuous (be + -ing) to talk about things we have already arranged for the future.

section.title: Future forms
section.sectiontitle: In some cases, it doesn't matter whether we use the Present continuous or going to.
section.text1a: I'm going to play football this evening.
section.text2: I'm going to see the doctor tomorrow.
section.sectiontitle2: In other cases, there is a clear difference in meaning:
section.text3a: We're going to get married one day.

section.title: Future forms
section.sectiontitle: We use will + verb to talk about things which we think will happen without any special plan or arrangement. We often use the short form.
section.text1a: I know I'll forget it if I don't write it down.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use won't + verb. In the question, we use will + subject + verb.
section.text3: I'm sure Sharapova will not win.

section.title: Future forms
section.sectiontitle: We also use be planning to and be thinking of to talk about future plans.
section.text1a: I'm planning to sell my scooter.
section.sectiontitle2: We use (be) due to to talk about a formal arrangement and (be) about to when something will happen very soon or immediately.
section.text3a: The plane's due to take off in about twenty minutes.
section.text4a: Jill's about to have a baby.
